parameter.description: This parameter specifies the Internet Protocol (IP) address of the network device from which calls are permitted.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of the attribute(s) to clear.

context.name: SIP
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Internet Protocol (IP) addresses configured for Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) network devices. These are the IP addresses from which network messages (SIP) will be honored. The Execution Server's own IP addresses must be entered for inter-group calling to be permitted. It is recommended that you also add the IP addresses of the other core BroadWorks servers to the SIP access control list, including the Network Server, Media Server, and Conferencing Server. Only IP addresses may be used; fully qualified domain names (FQDNs) are not accepted.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the Internet Protocol (IP) addresses configured for Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) network devices.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) network devices to the access list.

parameter.name: netAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the Internet Protocol (IP) address of the network device from which calls are permitted.

parameter.name: transportProtocol
parameter.description: This parameter specifies which transport type is used by this device. When this parameter value is set to "Unspecified", either protocol is allowed.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to add through the add command.

parameter.name: description
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the character-based description of the device from which calls are permitted.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify the attributes of the Internet Protocol (IP) addresses configured for Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) network devices.

parameter.name: netAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the Internet Protocol (IP) address of the network device from which calls are permitted.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: transportProtocol
parameter.description: This parameter specifies which transport type is used by this device. When this parameter value is set to "Unspecified", either protocol is allowed.

parameter.name: description
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the character-based description of the device from which calls are permitted.

command.description: This command is used to delete Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) network devices from the access list.

parameter.name: netAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the Internet Protocol (IP) address of the network device from which calls are permitted.

command.name: clear
command.description: This command is used to clear (set to no value) the Internet Protocol (IP) addresses or description configured for Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) network devices.

parameter.name: netAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the Internet Protocol (IP) address of the network device from which calls are permitted.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of the attribute to delete.

context.name: OverloadControls
context.description: This level is used to view and modify overload control settings for the Execution Server. Since the Execution Server is a line-side facing element for BroadWorks, it can experience an overload condition. In a disaster or emergency scenario, the Execution Server may receive a burst of call originations from access devices. The OverloadControls feature allows the Execution Server to gracefully manage an overload condition without affecting calls in progress. The Execution Server constantly samples input queue delays. A configurable sample size N is defined (default is 100). If the average value of the last N queue delay becomes too long, then an overload condition is triggered. The Execution Server maintains two overloaded zones: yellow and red. (The green zone represents a non-overload situation.) Each zone has a separate configurable queue delay threshold that, when exceeded, causes the Execution Server to go to the next zone. It is possible to go directly from the green to red overload zone. Once in an overload zone, the server continues to monitor queue delays. When the queue delay average lowers below another predefined threshold, the server is eligible to go to the next lower overload zone (red to yellow or yellow to green). However, to avoid hysteresis (constantly alternating between overload zones), there is a minimum time period that must be met. The minimum time period value does not apply to transitioning to a higher overload zone, only returning to a lower one. In the yellow zone, the Execution Server continues to process existing calls in progress. If new call originations are detected, only half of them are processed and the other half are denied. The server continues to process messages for existing calls in progress because some of the messages may be BYE or CANCEL requests which remove calls, thereby reducing the load on the server. In the red zone, the Execution Server continues to process existing calls in progress. If new call originations are detected, they are denied. The Execution Server remains in the corresponding overload zone until the queue delay returns to an acceptable threshold value and the minimum time period in the zone is met. If the system is configured to allow emergency calls during overload, then originations matching the call type "Emergency" in the system calling plan are allowed to progress. Calls are denied on the originating side. A user is allowed to add additional call terminations (for example, using flash, or the Call Manager). However, additional originations from the device are not allowed. Unless the user is already on a call, Call Manager originated calls are also denied during overload. The Call Manager shows a "Forbidden" message.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the Overload Controls settings.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify the Overload Controls settings.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: enabled
parameter.description: This parameter turns Overload Controls on and off.

parameter.name: sipOverloadAction
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the action to be performed on an incoming message. When this parameter value is set to "Redirect", a 302 Moved Temporarily error appears. When this parameter value is set to "Error", a 503 Service Unavailable error appears. When this parameter value is set to "Decline", a 603 + Retry-After error appears. When this parameter value is set to "Drop", the system does not respond. When this parameter value is set to "Unavailable", a 480 + Retry-After error appears.

parameter.name: percentMemoryInUseToEnterYellowZone
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the amount of memory usage needed for the system to enter the yellow overloaded zone.

parameter.name: percentMemoryInUseToEnterRedZone
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the amount of memory usage needed for the system to enter the red overloaded zone.

parameter.name: percentMemoryInUseToLeaveYellowZone
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the amount of memory usage needed for the system to leave the yellow overloaded zone.

parameter.name: percentMemoryInUseToLeaveRedZone
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the amount of memory usage needed for the system to leave the red overloaded zone.

parameter.name: allowEmergencyCallsInOverload
parameter.description: This parameter enables emergency calls during an overload. When this parameter value is set to "true", emergency calls are allowed during overload. '''NOTE''': Due to the nature of Media Gateway Control Protocol (MGCP) messaging, emergency calls from MGCP devices are blocked in the same manner as normal calls, regardless of the system's emergency call configuration.

parameter.name: maxPacketAgeInMilliseconds
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the maximum time in milliseconds for a message to remain in queue.

parameter.name: maxPacketAgeDuringOverloadInMilliseconds
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the maximum time in milliseconds for a message to remain in queue during overload.

parameter.name: supportCongestionManagement
parameter.description: This parameter enables the Retry-After support and related congestion algorithm.

parameter.name: retryAfterMinSeconds
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the minimum time that the neighboring network element waits before sending messages to the Execution Server. The Retry-After header value included in the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) 503 Retry-After header, sent to the neighboring Network Element (NE) in response to a dropped message, is a number selected randomly from the range between this and the [[maxRetryAfterInSeconds]] values (effective only if the [[supportCongestionManagement]] option is set to "true").

parameter.name: retryAfterMaxSeconds
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the maximum time that the neighboring network element waits before sending messages to the Execution Server. The Retry-After header value included in the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) 503 Retry-After header, sent to the neighboring Network Element (NE) in response to a dropped message, is a number selected randomly from the range between this and the [[minRetryAfterInSeconds]] values (effective only if the [[supportCongestionManagement]] option is set to "true").

parameter.name: neighborMaxServiceUnavailable
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the maximum time that a neighbor is considered unavailable. This is done to prevent the Execution Server from placing the downstream neighbor in congestion control state for an unreasonable period.

parameter.name: neighborTrafficSamplingPeriod
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the time (in seconds) over which the neighbor traffic is sampled to determine traffic load and detect overload condition.

parameter.name: aggregateQueueMonitoring
parameter.description: This parameter enables monitoring using an aggregate of data from the processing queues, versus each queue separately.

context.name: CallP
context.description: This level is used to view and modify Overload Controls settings related to call processing.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view Overload Controls settings related to call processing.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify Overload Controls settings related to call processing.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: numSamples
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the queue delay sample size needed before the Overload Controls are activated.

parameter.name: minTimeInZone
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the minimum amount of time, in milliseconds, that the server stays in a specific zone before returning to a lower one.

parameter.name: delayToEnterYellowZoneInMilliseconds
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the average queue delay (in milliseconds) required to enter the yellow zone. This value must be greater than the [[DelayToLeaveYellow]] value but less than the [[DelayToLeaveRed]] value.

parameter.name: delayToEnterRedZoneInMilliseconds
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the average queue delay (in milliseconds) required to enter the red zone. This value must be greater than the [[DelayToLeaveRed]] value.

parameter.name: delayToLeaveYellowZoneInMilliseconds
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the average queue delay in milliseconds required to exit the yellow zone. This value must be less than the [[DelayToEnterYellow]] value.

parameter.name: delayToLeaveRedZoneInMilliseconds
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the average queue delay (in milliseconds) required to exit the red zone. This value must be greater than the [[DelayToEnterYellow]] value but less than the [[DelayToEnterRed]] value.

context.name: ManagedNeighbors
context.description: This level is used to view, add, modify, and delete ManagedNeighbors-related information.

context.name: Capabilities
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the managed neighbor capability parameters. These parameters are used to store manually set capability parameters for multiple-managed neighbor instances.

command.name: get

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add a new neighbor and its capability parameters.
